in the outer zones is greater than that of which the inner zones are composed.
It does not increase, however, in the regular ratio of the respective diameters
of the zones; for the cells of the outer zones, being usually both larger and
more widely separated from each other than are those of the inner, are
less numerous in proportion; thus in Plate II, Fig 2 there are 28 cells in
the <s>under</s> innermost row, and only 49 in the outermost, though the latter is more
than twice the diameter of the former. The increase in the number of
the segments is accomplished by the occasional <u>interpolation</u> of an
additional segment, communicating directly with the one immediately
interior to it, between the two segments <s>,</s>  which spring from the annular
stolon on either side of the latter; as is shown in <s>Fig</s> Plate I, Figs. 8, 9, <u>a</u>. Hence it is
obvious that prolongations of sarcode giving origin to new segments, <s>may</s>
<s>originate from any part of each annulus, although they are ordinarily</s>
although ordinarily put forth rather by the connecting 'stolons' than by the segments themselves,
may originate from any part of the annulus.
This is shown still more forcibly by the occasional occurrence of
irregularities, such as that represented in Plate IV, Fig 12.

19  The cells of the last-formed zone communicate with the exterior
by the very same kind of radial passages, as in other instances communicate
with the next zone; and the external orifices of these from the pores
